text: I've been doing trading for two years live now. I had a period on the simulator before, but I had a full two years live now. I would say that on the ladder versus just having a simple chat, you feel more the participants. You see on the chat you can't see who wants to buy, who wants to sell. On the ladder, you can't hide yourself. If you want to buy, you have to put your order on the ladder. So automatically you see it and I feel like it's easier to feel the temperature of the market. So I have a couple of patterns that I like to trade on the ladder. For example, when I see a very quick acceleration... the price. Sometimes it's just one participant who needs to execute a trade and I like to try to to go against and try to steal one or two ticks in the other side of the market. Otherwise with the ladders sometimes I try to front run the big others when there is someone for example on the round number who wants to sell let's say 2000 bund at a certain price, I try to frontrun this price and to get couple ticks from this. I think to develop your abilities, especially at the beginning, you need to spend a lot of hours in front of the ladders. At the beginning it seems a little bit like a foreign language, so many times you don't After practice, you just get more and more obvious and I think at the beginning what's important is to take notes of your observations, to see what works, what doesn't work on the market and then you need to evolve with the market because you can see certain habits that take the market for a couple of weeks and then it's gone and you have... another kind of another type of market playing so it's good to have a good memory of what

On the ladder, you can't hide yourself. If you want to buy, you have to put your order on the ladder. So automatically you see it and I feel like it's easier to feel the temperature of the market. So I have a couple of patterns that I like to trade on the ladder. For example, when I see a very quick acceleration... the price. Otherwise with the ladders sometimes I try to front run the big others when there is someone for example on the round number who wants to sell let's say 2000 bund at a certain price, I try to frontrun this price and to get couple ticks from this. I think to develop your abilities, especially at the beginning, you need to spend a lot of hours in front of the ladders. At the beginning it seems a little bit like a foreign language, so many times you don't After practice, you just get more and more obvious and I think at the beginning what's important is to take notes of your observations, to see what works, what doesn't work on the market and then you need to evolve with the market because you can see certain habits that take the market for a couple of weeks and then it's gone and you have... another kind of another type of market playing so it's good to have a good memory of what

text: the market and then you need to evolve with the market because you can see certain habits that take the market for a couple of weeks and then it's gone and you have... another kind of another type of market playing so it's good to have a good memory of what happened in the past and try to adapt your technique to the to the current current condition of the market. I don't have a special edge there's not something particular that I execute to do a little bit everything so sometimes it can be just scalping in an area if I expect the market to be quiet or sometimes if I see for example sometimes you can see people reloading the the same price again and again so you can try to go in a in a direction and you can see this in the in the price ladder when some For example, someone tried to sell 40 and you have always the guy who reloads the bid at 40, 40, so you can try to get long on this and you expect the market to go up when the people are done selling at this price, then most of the time they have to pay in the other side and you get the move after when you have a compression of the market sometimes in a very tiny area, as soon as we get out of this area then when we break you have the the release of the energy of the market it takes a while to become profitable at first when i started in my previous company we had a training of three months then another period on the simulator and i would say that three months on the simulator. I started to be profitable. So I would say it takes about six months to become profitable. And then you need, I think a little bit more to start to increase your size and to cover your costs and automatically to have your account going up. I think there is a lot of tough parts

text: three months on the simulator. I started to be profitable. So I would say it takes about six months to become profitable. And then you need, I think a little bit more to start to increase your size and to cover your costs and automatically to have your account going up. I think there is a lot of tough parts profitable and successful trader. I think you need to like competition and at least to not be to not give up at the first barriers because it's very complicated even after when you start being profitable many times you will have a good trend having a Many many days profitable and suddenly you can have just one bad event that kills couple days of work in some in sometimes in couple seconds So it's sometimes it's tough to go home after such bad days, but you know, it's part of the game and you You have to forget this for the next day and take every day as a new challenge It can be very different, depending on what I'm doing. If I'm just scalping, maybe I will hold the trade for between one second and three minutes. Then if I'm positioning, it can take between five minutes if I have the perfect timing and everything goes right, or sometimes it can take 30 minutes, one hour, two hours. really depends on the kind of day and the kind of trade. For example, if you have a long position and suddenly you see someone who smashed the price in the other side that can take me out of the trade or at least I will cut some of my position. I try to not cut my entire position at once and you look at the market most of the time you want to take the same and then you're more comfortable to adjust the trade. I never had to my position.

So I know some people are adding and can have amazing trades, but. For me, yeah, it doesn't suit my technique. I already tried without charts because sometimes the chart system just didn't work for one day or two. And yeah, you can survive. You have to adapt your strategy. I feel like it's a little bit more difficult to position without charts because sometimes you're a little bit lost on the long term. but it's very good to scalp and I know some people that don't even use charts and just Scalp or use the scalper use the flipper in the market But me without charts I prefer only to take a couple ticks in a certain area when you fill the market. I think a very good habit is to especially at the beginning of your career is to write the pattern you recognize on the on the market and then you need to remember those things when it comes back because sometimes you can have a certain action on the price ladder and that might be gone for six months and suddenly when it comes back if you can quickly remember what happened last time and execute the trade that can be very profitable so number one habit i would say observation and also taking trades even if it's with two loads or so many so many traders are just watching watching and i think when you watch you don't really learn

text: Sometimes we also have special events in the market like the last day of the month. So it's always a changing game and you have to evolve to stay in the game and to take the most... benefits. Yeah I try to do a mix of every information we have so that can be charts, profile, what I see on the ladder and I would say that my trade would become with an analysis of the of the charts, profile and the fundamental and then the ladder will be more for the execution price I can and sometimes I also have specific trades that I execute only because of the ladder as I said if there's a big order or stuff like that. Yes I struggle with flippers so I just don't touch it at all but I know during lunch time some people are specialized or during quiet to play with the flippers and I have absolutely no idea how it works so I just when I see stuff like that I just stay out. Yeah there is no way to find out as long as it's not as we don't touch this price but for me with the experience I would say that most of the big orders that are away away from the market Like far away from the market, they tend to be real, especially on round numbers or on special levels. And, for example, at the opposite, if you have a big order that comes in a quiet period, without any reason, at only two ticks from the current price, it's probably a fake order. stuff like that.
